Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Nanoimprintor for Nanotechnology, Energy and Bioengineering Research, Education and Training

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop innovative methods to assemble and manufacture nanoscale materials and devices for applications in photonics, phononics, electronics, and chemical and biological sensing. The approach is to use the advanced lithographic methods of the proposed nanoimprintor to define and probe structures with desired complexity and with nanometer scale features that will transform our fundamental understanding of physical phenomena and biological processes and open doors to new devices for a wide-range of applications.
The intellectual merit of the research, utilizing the proposed nanoimprintor, is to pattern molecular, carbon-based, and inorganic nanocrystalline materials into functional architectures, to explore fundamental phenomena, and to exploit these materials in optical, electrical, energy, mechanical, and sensing devices. Mechanical systems show unique properties at the nanometer scale that can be probed in fabricated structures and harnessed in ultrafast, low-power nanoelectromechanical devices. Surfaces patterned at nanometer and micron scales mimic the extraordinary chemical and mechanical properties of biological systems and are being engineered to influence cell function and tissue regeneration and enabling model organs to be constructed.
The broader impact of the proposed tool is to the research and training of a diverse body of students, teachers, and researchers. The tool will be open to current and future users at Penn and regional academic and industrial institutions. It will be used by undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs from a wide-range of academic disciplines in new course curricula and research, as well being used in demonstrations to K-12 students and teachers.

Institution.Name: University of Pennsylvania
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed at acquiring a modern, state-of-the-art, nanoimprint lithography system to enable a wide range of materials and devices to be patterned in parallel. The tool allows patterning across samples as large as six inches in diameter with resolution as high as ten nanometers by nanoimprint lithography. A template is used to print the desired pattern which is subsequently fixed into the sample by the use of heat or light. The system also has the flexibility to combine nanoimprint lithography with high resolution photolithography. The tool was purchased, installed, and qualified in the University of Pennsylvania's Wolf Nanofabrication Facility, a central research and teaching Facility open to Penn and external academic and industrial users. The tool provides a unique capability, previously missing in the region, meeting the needs of the community and at the leading edge in training students in advanced nanofabrication techniques.

The nanoimprint lithography system is central to research at the forefront of diverse fields and since its installation has been used to understand physical phenomena and biological systems important for applications in the diverse areas of nanotechnology, energy, and bioengineering research; critical to next generation technologies and America's competitiveness in these fields. Examples of research accomplishments include the design of tunable and printable optical filters fabricated on flexible, bendable and curved surfaces; the patterning of materials and devices for more efficient solar photovoltaics; the patterning of semiconducting materials for flexible electronic devices; and the design of surfaces to manipulate and understand the behavior of cells and their function. The tool is being used to educate undergraduate and graduate students by being incorporated in the syllabi of formal courses taught in the University of Pennsylvania's Nanofabrication Facility and through student research experiences. The tool is also featured in K-12 outreach activities, such as visits to the Nanofabrication Facility during Nanoday at Penn.


Last Modified: 01/17/2012
Modified by: Cherie Kagan

    Nanoimprint Lithography System

The nanoimprint lithography system is central to research at the forefront of diverse fields and since its installation has been used to understand physical phenomena and biological systems important for applications in the diverse areas of nanotechnology, energy, and bioengineering research; critical to next generation technologies and America's competitiveness in these fields.
